details.title: Beetroot (Beta vulgaris)
details.body:
Beetroot is herbaceous plant that belongs to the family Amaranthaceae, the same family as chard and spinach. Typically a rich purple colour, beetroot can also be white or golden.
This plant originates from India, Mediterranean areas and the Atlantic coast of Europe, but it can be found all over the world today.
Due to its high sugar content, beetroot is delicious eaten raw but is more typically cooked or pickled. The heart-shaped leaves of beetroot are also edible and taste similarly to spinach.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• Beetroot can be also used for the manufacture of wine.
  • Beetroot was popular “mouth freshener” in the past and it was used to eliminate the smell of garlic.
  • Beetroot juice has been extensively used as a dye over the centuries and during the 19th century, women even used beetroot for dyeing their hair.

details.title: Benefits
details.body: Beetroots have exceptionally high nutritional value, they are full of vitamins and minerals and packed with powerful antioxidants. Red beetroots in fact have been ranked as one of the 10 most potent antioxidant vegetables! Beetroots are an excellent source of folic acid and a very good source of fibre, manganese and potassium. Its heart-shaped leaves, rich in calcium, iron and vitamins A and C, can be cooked up and enjoyed in the same way as spinach. Beetroot fibre has been shown to increase the number of white blood cells, which are responsible for detecting and eliminating abnormal cells.

details.title: Growing Beetroots
details.body: Beetroot prefer to be grown in moist, fertile soil in a sunny spot, but will also thrive in raised beds or pots. Although early sowings can be made from late winter, raising plants can be tricky, so for foolproof beetroot, sow seeds directly into the soil from mid-spring.

details.title: Courgette (Cucurbita pepo var. cylindrica)
details.body:
The courgette (or zucchini) is part of the Cucurbitaceae family and it’s native to Central America and Mexico. Courgette is grown year-round. Even though it is a fruit, it is usually cooked as a vegetable. It can however be eaten raw and it’s particularly nice when shredded and added onto a cold salad.
Courgettes are extremely easy to grow and produce a lot of harvest: expect three or four a week!

details.title: Tips
details.body:
• Courgettes are easy to grow from seed. They are best started off indoors in pots, but you can also sow them outdoors depending on the weather where you live.
  • For earlier crops or in cold regions sow seeds indoors from mid- to late April at 18-21°C. To sow outdoors, do so in late May/early June and cover with a protective material for at least couple of weeks.
  • Courgettes are hungry plants and will benefit from a rich soil. Be aware the roots of the plant will spread as much as the foliage so the soil need to be fertilized to that distance. Sprinkle some seaweed / poultry manure pellets a metre around the planting hole.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• The flower of the Courgette plant is also edible.
  • The courgette was one of Columbus’ discoveries.

details.title: Benefits
details.body: Courgettes contain very few calories and have a high water content, which makes them a dieter’s friend. They provide useful amounts of vitamin C which helps boost the immune system, as well as, potassium, which is key to controlling blood pressure. A courgette has more potassium than a banana.

details.title: Mint (Mentha)
details.body:
Mint is a perennial herb grown for its leaves, originating in the Mediterranean region. It is an extremely versatile plant used in cooking, to make a refreshing tea and as an ingredient in various products, particularly toothpaste, breath and air-fresheners and chewing gyms.
There are many different varieties of mint to choose from with leaves that smell completely different.

details.title: Tips
details.body:
• Give plants plenty of water, especially during hot, dry weather.
  • When plants have finished flowering in summer, cut flowered shoots back to 5cm (2in) above the surface of the compost.
  • Avoid growing different varieties of mint close together, whether in pots or the ground, as they can lose their individual scent and flavour.
  • When growing in pots, rejuvenate congested clumps by upturning the container, removing the root ball and splitting it in half. Repot a portion in the same container using fresh compost.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• Mint belongs to one of the most aromatic culinary herbs family, the Lamiaceae or Labiatae, with other famous “relatives” including: basil, rosemary, sage, savory, marjoram, oregano, hyssop, thyme, lavender, and perilla.
  • Ancient Romans, Hebrews and Greeks used mint to flavour cordials and fruit compotes also for baths, perfumes and as a room air freshener. Mint has been found in Egyptian tombs from as far back as 1000 BC!

details.title: Benefits
details.body:
It is an herb that has been used for hundreds of years for its remarkable medicinal properties. Mint has one of the highest antioxidant capacities of any food.
Mint contains menthol, a natural aromatic decongestant that helps to break up phlegm and mucus. Mint is a calming and soothing herb that has been used for thousands of years to aid with upset stomach or indigestion.

details.title: Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
details.body:
Tomatoes belong to the family of Nightshade, or Solanaceae and they are fruits, not vegetables, they have seeds.
Tomatoes originated in the South American Andes around the area of modern day Peru.
Most tomatoes we eat are red. However, other colors are possible: green, yellow, orange, pink, black, brown, purple or even white. There are more than 10,000 tomato varieties grown around the world!
Tomatoes are easy to grow and a couple of plants will produce hundreds of fruit from mid Summer right through to early Autumn.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• While tomatoes are perfectly safe and healthy to eat, their leaves are actually toxic!
  • They were first brought to Europe in the mid 1500’s; the French first called them “apple of love” and the Germans “apple of Paradise”!
  • Tomato derives from its original name ‘xitomatl’ in the Nahuatl (Aztec) language; it translates to “plump thing with a navel”!
  • Tomatoes can keep longer if you store them with their stem down.

details.title: Benefits
details.body: Tomatoes are rich in lycopene, an antioxidant that is good for the heart and effective against certain cancers. Cooked tomatoes are actually better for you than raw ones, as more beneficial chemicals are released. Tomatoes are also packed with vitamins A and C, calcium, potassium.

details.title: Tips:
details.body:
• Sow the seeds from late March to early April if you will be growing the plants outdoors or from late February to mid-March if you are planning on growing your tomatoes in a greenhouse.
  • Sow in small pots indoors. The young seedlings need to be kept at around 18°C. Transplant into 9cm pots when two true leaves have formed. When the flowers of the first truss are beginning to open, transfer to 23cm pots.
  • Tie the main stem to a vertical bamboo cane or wind it round a sturdy string.
  • Remove the sideshoots regularly when they are about 2.5cm long.

details.title: Potato (Solanaceae)
details.body:
The potato, of the Solanaceae family, originated in the area of present-day southern Peru and extreme north-western Bolivia. It was domesticated approximately 7,000–10,000 years ago and today consists the world’s fourth food staple – after corn, wheat and rice.
It’s a hugely versatile and a staple ingredient of many meals in one form or another - boiled, mashed, chipped or baked.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• Green potatoes are poisonous.
  • Potatoes were the first vegetable grown in space.
  • The introduction of the potato is estimated to have been greatly responsible for a quarter of the growth in world population and urbanization between 1700 and 1900!

details.title: Benefits
details.body: Potatoes are an excellent source of vitamin C and a good source of potassium and vitamin B6. It’s also fat, sodium and cholesterol-free.

details.title: Tips
details.body:
Potatoes are classified as being either earlies or maincrops. Early varieties (‘new potatoes’) are ready to harvest much sooner and Maincrop varieties have a better yield and produce larger potatoes.
  • Plant earlies around late March to early/mid-April, and Maincrops mid- to late April.
  • Potatoes need a sunny site away from frost pockets - the newly emerging foliage is susceptible to frost damage in April and May.
  • Keep crops well-watered in dry weather.
  • Prepare the ground the previous autumn or winter by digging in organic matter such as well-rotted animal manure.

details.title: Spinach (Spinacia oleracea)
details.body:
Spinach is a leafy crop belonging to the Chenopodiaceae family of plants, which is also known as the goosefoot family as the leaves look like the feet of a goose!
Spinach is a native plant of Persia (modern day Iran). It was most probably brought to Europe in about the 12th century.
Spinach can be grown to produce a crop all year round, making it a useful vegetable to grow when other greens might be in short supply.

details.title: Benefits
details.body:
Spinach is full of vitamins and minerals, including vitamin K, vitamin A, manganese, folate, magnesium, iron, copper, vitamin B2, vitamin B6, vitamin E, calcium, potassium, and vitamin C. In addition it contains 5.36 grams of protein per cup (cooked), making it one of the most protein-rich vegetables available.
Just half a cup of raw spinach counts as 1 of the 5 servings of fruits and vegetables you should eat a day.
Spinach is best eaten fresh; it loses nutritional properties with each passing day.

details.title: Interesting Facts
details.body:
• In the 1930’s U.S. spinach growers credited Popeye with a 33% increase in domestic spinach consumption.
  • Medieval artists extracted green pigment from spinach to use as an ink or paint.

details.title: Tips
details.body:
• Some cultivars can be overwintered for an early spring harvest. Winter cultivars need a sunny position, but summer types benefit from a little shade.
  • Sow winter varieties at the beginning of September (summer varieties mid- March to the end of May).
  • Spinach prefers to grow in soil where there has been lots of organic matter (e.g. compost, well-rotted manure) added and is well drained.

details.title: Aubergine (Solanum melongena)
details.body: The fruit is widely used in cooking. Aubergines were cultivated in China and India in the 5th century, but it was not introduced in Southern Europe until the 12th century. The producing countries comprise the Mediterranean area, China and Japan.

details.title: Interesting facts
details.body: • In 13th-century Italian traditional folklore, the eggplant was thought to cause insanity, and in 19th-century Egypt, insanity was said to be "more common and violent" when the eggplant was in season!

details.title: Benefits
details.body: Aubergines are an excellent source of dietary fibre. In addition it is high in minerals, such as copper, magnesium and manganese. They are also a good source of vitamins B1 and B6 and potassium.

details.title: Growing Aubergines
details.body:
• Although aubergines can be grown outside, they rarely do well except in mild areas or during very good summers.
  • Sow in January if you have a heated greenhouse and February for an unheated greenhouse.
  • When plants are 30cm (12in) high, remove the tip from the main stem.
  • Aubergines – like peppers, tomatoes and potatoes – are members of the Solanaceae family so consider your crop rotation and site them in an area where these plants have not been grown in the past two years.
  • Prepare the soil by digging it in winter and adding plenty of compost or well-rotted manure to enrich it.

details.title: Couve (Collard Greens)
details.body:
The plants are grown for their large, dark-colored, edible leaves and as a garden ornamental, mainly in Brazil, Portugal, the southern United States, many parts of Africa, the Balkans, northern Spain, and Kashmir.

They are available year-round, but are tastier and more nutritious in the cold months.

Collard greens are members of the underrated cabbage family, Brassica oleracea.

details.title: Interesting facts
details.body: • In Portuguese and Brazilian cuisine, collard greens (or couve) is a common accompaniment to fish and meat dishes.

details.title: Benefits
details.body:
• Like kale, collard greens contain substantial amounts of vitamin K in a 100 gram serving.
  • Collard greens are rich sources of vitamin A, vitamin C, and manganese, and moderate sources of calcium and vitamin B6.

details.title: Growing Couve
details.body:
• Farmers plant collard greens usually two times per year: early in the spring and during the summer.
  • Collard greens propagates via seed.
  • Collard greens produces dry fruit which splits to release numerous, small seed.
  • Harvest takes place 6 to 8 weeks after sowing.

details.title: Garlic (Allium sativum)
details.body:
Garlic is a fundamental component in many or most dishes of various regions, including eastern Asia, South Asia, Southeast Asia, the Middle East, northern Africa, southern Europe, and parts of Latin America. In 2016, world production of garlic was 26.6 million tones!

Garlic is easy to grow and can be grown year-round in mild climates.

details.title: Interesting facts
details.body:
• The psychological term for fear of garlic is Alliumphobia.
  • In ancient Greece, brides carried bouquets of herbs and garlic, not flowers.
  • You can use garlic to make glue! The sticky juice in garlic cloves is often used as an adhesive for delicate projects.

details.title: Benefits
details.body:
Some of the many health benefits of garlic include:
Garlic has profound effects on lowering blood pressure, it successfully kills a wide range of bacteria that cause infections but also has the capacity to prevent infections from occurring in the first place. It also possesses anti-fungal and anti-viral properties, making it an all-round immunity booster.
The use of garlic for its cholesterol reducing effects is one of its most popular roles across the world, and is something it does fairly well; being able to reduce serum LDL by as much as 10-15%.

details.title: Growing Garlic
details.body:
• Hoeing weeds risks damaging developing bulbs so hand weeding when weeds are small is preferable.
  • During spring and early summer watering during dry spells will improve yields. But don’t water once the bulbs are large and well-formed, as this could encourage rotting.
  • Yellowing foliage is a sign that bulbs are reaching this stage of maturity.
  • Snip off any flowers that form.
  • Buy bulbs from a garden centre or mail order supplier. Avoid those from the supermarket – they may carry disease and not be suited to the climate.
  • Garlic needs a chilling period so is best planted in late autumn or early winter.

details.title: Onion (Allium Cepa)
details.body: The onion is a biennial plant belonging to the Amaryllidaceous family. It’s cultivated and used around the world. As a food item, onions are usually served cooked but can also be eaten raw or used to make pickles or chutneys. Food uses of onion date back thousands of years in China, Egypt and Persia.

details.title: Interesting facts
details.body:
• Ancient Egyptians worshipped onions; in fact, onions were often placed in the burial tombs of pharoahs, as they were believed to bring about prosperity in the afterlife.
  • In the Middle Ages, onions were an acceptable form of currency, and was used to pay for rent, goods and services — and even as gifts!

details.title: Benefits
details.body:
Onions are often characterized as ‘super-foods’ because they are full of antioxidants, multiple vitamins and minerals. They are a good source of vitamin B6, vitamin B9, vitamin C, folate, and potassium. There are multiple phytonutrients that are found in onions. As a result the benefits of onions span from having strong detoxifying, as well as, anti-fungal and antimicrobial properties, to being able to boost our immune system, aiding with digestion and management of anaemia and diabetes, to mention a few.

Raw, fresh cut or ground onion has the best influence on the health. If you cannot stand its smell and you must cook it, you will need to use at least four onions to achieve the same effect.

details.title: Tips
details.body:
• Onions can be grown from onion sets or bulbs (immature onions) and planted either in late autumn for overwintering for the earliest possible summer crop, or sown in early spring. Alternatively it is possible, although harder, to grow onions from seed.
  • Onions do not require constant watering. Some people even say that too much watering can spoil their flavour. In normal summer weather I will leave them to grow naturally. In prolonged absence of summer rain showers, I may give them a good soaking to tide them over (every 10 days or so). In extreme hot weather they may need watering every 3 or 4 days.

details.title: Thyme (Thymus)
details.body:
Thyme is of the genus Thymus of the mint family (Lamiaceae), and a relative of the oregano genus Organum.

A native of Southern Europe, thyme is now grown the world over from Africa to Russia - it proves its versatility and it certainly deserves a place in your garden.

details.title: Interesting facts
details.body:
• The ancient Greeks used it in their baths and burnt it as incense in their temples, believing it was a source of courage.
  • The spread of thyme throughout Europe was thought to be due to the Romans, as they used it to purify their rooms and to give an aromatic flavor to cheese and liqueurs.
  • In the European middle Ages, the herb was placed beneath pillows to aid sleep and ward off nightmares.

details.title: Growing Thyme
details.body:
• Thyme likes a well-drained light soil, it should not be too rich in nutrients which will only make the plant 'leggy' and loose its compact shape.
  • Being a native of the Mediterranean it needs a place in full sun.
  • It is generally planted in the spring, and thereafter grows as a perennial. It can be propagated by seed, cuttings, or dividing rooted sections of the plan.

details.title: Kashk e Bademjan (Iran)
details.body:
by Mitra

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 2 aubergines
  • 10 tsps of oil
  • 2 chopped onions
  • 4 choppedgarlic cloves
  • 1 tsps of turmeric
  • 2 tsps of dried mint
  • 5 tsps of Iranian sauce (kashk) or sour cream
  • 5 walnuts

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Wash all vegetables
  2. Cut each aubergine into 4 pieces and fry in 6 spoons of boiling oil. When they’ve finished frying, add half a glass of water.
  3. Put the lid on and let it cook slowly on a minimum heat until the water evaporates.
  4. In a separate pan fry the onions and garlic with a little oil until golden. At this stage add turmeric and mint. Note: mint causes the oil to finish quicker so you might have to add more oil to it while its cooking. Then immediately turn the cooker off and put aside for later.
  5. Mush the aubergines together into a paste. Add the Iranian sauce and mix them together.
  6. To serve, place the mashed aubergines on a dish. Dot the fried onions on the top for decoration (but also for taste). If you like walnuts you can chop and sprinkle on the top. Serve with plenty of flat breads!

details.title: Beetroot Smoothie (United Kingdom)
details.body:
by John

This recipe serves three to four people

details.title: Note
details.body: You will need a food processor or a smoothie maker

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• ½ large beetroot
  • 1 banana
  • ½ desert apple
  • 2cm piece of fresh ginger
  • 250ml full fat milk
  • 250ml natural yogurt

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Thinly slice and chop the raw beetroot, banana and apple, and place in the food processor.
  2. Add grated fresh ginger, followed by the milk and yogurt.
  3. Blitz for about one minute until smooth.
  4. Serve immediately in glasses.

This smoothie is so quick and simple to make each day and it's very tasty, looks great and is really good for your health.

The ginger in this recipe can be replaced with lemon. You can also change the recipe by adding spices such as cinnamon or you can experiment with other fruit.

details.title: Dolma and Dao (Iraq)
details.body:
by Sherine

This recipe serves four people



Dolma and Dao are traditionally used in Iraq as a picnic food. Food is assembled at home and then the pan is carried to the picnic site and cooked slowly over a wood fire.

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 500g small courgettes
  • 500g small aubergines
  • 750g chard or grape vine leaves
  • 4 tomatoes
  • 2 green peppers
  • 2 red peppers
  • 4 onions
  • 1 tbsp vegetable oil
For the stuffing
  • 2 cups rice soaked in the water for 15 min and drained
  • 400g minced lamb
  • 4 cloves garlic
  • small bunch of fresh dill
  • 1 tomato finally chopped
  • 2 tbsp tomato paste
  • black pepper to taste
  • salt to taste
  • chilli pepper to taste
  • 2 tsp of sumaak or a lemon juice
For the Dao
  • 1cup yoghurt
  • a little lemon juice
  • a pinch of salt
  • 1½ cups of cold water
For the bottom of the pan
  • half a small chicken cut in to small pieces
  • 1 cup of broad beans

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Wash the chard in hot water and separate the hard stem from the leaves
  2. Place the chicken pieces in a large pan with a little oil, seal the meat and then add the broad beans
To prepare the stuffing
  1. Place the rice in a bowl and add all the stuffing ingredients. Mix well
  2. Hollow the courgettes, aubergines, onions, tomatoes and peppers
  3. Fill the vegetables with the stuffing and start assembling in a pan on top of the chicken and the beans. Once all the vegetables are 2/3 filled full start rolling the leaves
  4. Place a small amount of the stuffing in the middle of the chard leaf and roll into a cigar shape. Place on top of the vegetables in the pan
  5. Add the lemon juice and then enough water to reach up to half the height of the layers. Cover with a lid and cook for 30 mins

details.title: To Serve
details.body:
To serve place a flat serving tray face down over the pot. Turn the pot upside down carefully and the magic happens!

Serve alongside Dao (the Iraqi national dish)

Mix all the Dao ingredients well and serve in glasses.

Dolma and Dao are traditionally used in Iraq as a picnic food. Food is assembled at home and then the pan is carried to the picnic site and cooked slowly over a wood fire.

We can’t think of a better way to spend a day outdoors while eating delicious dolma and washing it down with cold refreshing Dao. Any time!

details.title: Feijao de Oleo de Palma (Angola)
details.body:
by Belmira

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 200g of dry white beans or one can of beans
  • 1ltr water
  • 1 medium onion
  • 1/3 cup of palm oil
  • ½ cup of cassava flour (garri)
  • bunch of couves
  • 4 bananas

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. If using dried beans soak them overnight in plenty of water.
  2. Next day place the beans in a pan with the water, a whole onion and palm oil (if using the canned beans first slowly fry the onion and then add the beans and 400ml of water - continue cooking in the same way)
  3. Simmer gently with a lid on until desired thickness is achieved. It should be a lovely thick stew of a dark orange colour.
  4. Pour it into a shallow dish.
  5. Meanwhile dry roast cassava flour (garri) while stirring constantly. When it is golden, sprinkle on the top of the dish.
  6. Serve with spring greens and a banana- it does work!

details.title: Extra Tip
details.body: If you are serving this dish to a child in Angola you would slice a banana and place the little discs on the top.

details.title: Salted swordfish in tomato sauce (DR Congo)
details.body:
by Yves

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 400g salted swordfish (or salted cod)
  • 1 medium onion
  • 2 cloves of garlic (or to taste)
  • 1 tin of tomatoes
  • ¼ vegetable stock cube
  • ½ red pepper
  • ½ green pepper
  • vegetable oil for frying

details.title: Method
details.body:
To prepare the fish soak it in cold water overnight. You might need to change the water up to three times to remove the salt.
  1. Fry the fish in the oil, one or two pieces at a time. Ensure your fish is cooked through. Take it out of the pan and leave to one side.
  2. Once you finish frying your fish, place sliced onions and finely chopped garlic in the same pan and fry until onion becomes translucent.
  3. Add the tinned tomatoes and stir, followed by the rest of the vegetables and a little stock cube.
  4. Taste the sauce and adjust the flavouring if necessary.
  5. Continue cooking on a low heat until the sauce reduces.
  6. To serve pour the sauce over the fish and enjoy.

details.title: Ashak (Afghanistan)
details.body:
by Safia

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
For the dough

  • 1 cup plain flour (and some extra for dusting)
  • ½ tsp salt
  • ½ cup water

For the filling

  • 1 leek
  • 1 tsp salt
  • 1 tbsp oil

For the bean sauce

  • ½ cup oil
  • 1 tin kidney beans
  • ½ tin chopped tomatoes
  • ½ tsp salt

For the Kashk sauce

  • 3 tbsp kashk (or sour cream)
  • 2 cloves of garlic mashed
  • ½ cup yoghurt
  • dried mint
  • black pepper
  • fresh coriander leaves

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. To make the dough combine the flour, salt and water
  2. Kneed it until it forms a firm but still soft ball and leave it to one side covered with cling film
  3. To make the filling slice the leek finely, add salt and oil and squeeze it with your hands gently to soften it
  4. Roll out the dough you prepared earlier on a floured surface to a thickness of 2-3mm.
  5. Use a cup, mug or cookie cutter to cut out circles. In the middle of each circle place 1tbsp of filling. Fold each circle in half to form half-moon shaped parcels and stick the edges together firmly. Sprinkle with flour to stop them sticking and leave to one side while you make the bean sauce.
  6. Heat the oil in the pan and add the tomatoes. Simmer for five minutes. Add the kidney beans and salt before reducing the liquid until it forms a sauce
  7. Boil the water in a large pan and slowly place the parcels in one-by-one. Boil gently for 5-7 minutes then remove from the pan and drain the water
  8. To make the kashk sauce mix all the ingredients together

details.title: To Serve
details.body:
To serve spread 2 tbsp of kashk sauce on a plate, place four parcels on top of the sauce on each plate. Drizzle with two spoons of kashk sauce over the parcels followed by two spoons of bean sauce.

To finish decorate with dried mint and black pepper to taste followed by chopped coriander leaves and serve with lots of flat bread.

details.title: Zereshk Polow (Iran)
details.body:
by Mitra

This recipe serves two people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 2 cups of basmati rice
  • 4 cups of water
  • 1 large chopped onion
  • 10tsp of oil
  • Half a chicken
  • 1/3 cup of dried barberries
  • 1 soup spoon of sugar
  • 2 pinches of saffron (put it in a small glass and add a very little bit of hot water to it)

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Wash all the vegetables
  2. Fry the onions in a pan with a bit of oil until golden. Remove from the pan and put aside for later.
  3. Cut the chicken into small pieces and fry them. Or you can cook the half chicken in a boiling water for half an hour, and then fry it in a frying pan. After the chicken is golden put it aside.
  4. Put a little oil in a frying pan and when hot add the barberries and sugar. Stir quickly for no more than four or five seconds (or they will be overcooked). Take out the barberries and put them aside.
  5. Cook the rice in plenty of water according to the instructions. Once you finish cooking the rice, drain the water and place in a dome shape on a large platter.
  6. To serve, mix the chicken and rice very gently, making sure not to break the rice grains.
  7. Sprinkle the saffron water over the rice in a design of your choice, followed by the fried onions and barberries. Decoration is as important as taste in Iranian cooking. If it looks good it will taste even better.

details.title: Hoppers with Eggs (Sri Lanka)
details.body:
by Suhana

This recipe makes 18-20 hoppers

Hoppers are eaten at breakfast time (or just on the go) in Sri Lanka. You can also make a sweet hopper by sprinkling brown sugar, cinnamon or coconut instead of an egg. Grated chocolate sounds good too ... yum!

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 750ml coconut milk
  • 1kg rice flour
  • 200ml water
  • 1tsp yeast
  • 3 eggs
  • 5tsp sugar
  • salt to taste
  • hopper pan (similar to a little wok)
  • eggs (optional)

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. In a large bowl place rice flour and yeast. Start adding eggs and water. Mix well, cover the bowl and let it rise for 45 mins.
  2. After the mixture has risen add coconut milk, sugar and salt. Mix well until the mixture becomes a thick batter.
  3. Heat the hopper pan and when hot pour 80ml of batter in it and at this point swirl it quickly to coat the sides of the pan. When the crust forms on a hopper its ready to be eaten
  4. At this point break an egg and gently place it in the centre of the hopper. Cover the pan with a lid, reduce to a low heat and cook until the egg is ready.
  5. Remove hopper from the pan with a spatula. Serve and enjoy!

details.title: Chickpea, spinach and apricot soup (United Kingdom)
details.body:
by Yvonne

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 2 tbsp oil
  • 2 finely chopped onions
  • 2 crushed cloves of garlic
  • 1½ tsp ground cinnamon
  • ½ tsp chilli
  • 2 tbsp tomato puree
  • 150g chopped apricots
  • Grated rind of half a lemon
  • 4 tsp lemon juice
  • 1.2 ltr stock vegetable or chicken
  • 250g cooked chickpeas
  • 200g shredded spinach
  • salt and pepper
  • plain yoghurt to serve

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Cook onion gently in oil in covered pan.
  2. Add spices, stir for one minute.
  3. Add tomato puree, lemon rind and juice, stock, chickpeas and apricots. Cover and simmer for 20 minutes.
  4. Cool and liquidise.
  5. Return to a clean pan and simmer for five minutes.
  6. Add spinach and cook until it wilts.
  7. Serve with a swirl of plain yoghurt.

details.title: Chestnut and Brussels Sprouts Hotpot (United Kingdom)
details.body:
by Lottie

This recipe serves four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 200g peeled and ready cooked chestnuts
  • 1 cup pearled spelt or pearled barley
  • 4 or 5 shallots per person + a little oil
  • 4 or 5 brussels sprouts per person
  • 4 carrots cut into chunks
  • 4 or 5 mushrooms per person cut into chunks
  • 1½ litres of stock made using mushroom or vegetable stock cubes, or home-made stock
  • 4 sprigs of thyme
  • salt and pepper
  • parsley to decorate

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Lightly toast the pearled spelt or barley. Add 1½ litres of stock, bring to the boil and then simmer while preparing the vegetables. The spelt barley will take 1-11/4 hours to cook.
  2. In the meantime brown the shallots in a little oil until they are starting to soften. Add the shallots with the other prepared vegetables to the stock and pearled spelt or barley. Add the sprigs of fresh thyme and salt and pepper to taste. Check that the vegetables and grains are covered - add a little extra water or stock if the stew looks dry.
  3. When the vegetables and grains are nearly cooked add the ready cooked chestnuts to heat through. Adjust the seasoning.
  4. Serve in bowls and top with fresh chopped parsley. Good with chunky bread or rolls.

details.title: Calulu de Peixe (Angola)
details.body:
by Belmira

This recipe serves three to four people

details.title: Ingredients
details.body:
• 1kg dried smoked fish
  • 1 onion, finely chopped
  • 3 tomatoes, chopped
  • 1 scotch bonnet chilli, finely chopped
  • 500g okra, trimmed and sliced
  • 500g sweet potato leaves (or spring greens or kale)
  • 4 garlic cloves, chopped
  • 1¼ cups red palm oil
  • salt to taste
  • 1 tbsp lemon juice
  • 1 sweet potato
  • 1 cassava root

details.title: Method
details.body:
1. Wash the dried and smoked fish thoroughly. Place it in a bowl and cover with cold water and leave overnight. You might need to change the water a few times.
  2. Drain the water and put aside.
  3. Prepare all the vegetables: peel potatoes and cassava and slice into 2cm discs. In a large saucepan, alternate layers of fish and all the vegetables.
  4. Pour the palm oil, scotch bonnet chilli and salt (to taste) over the contents of the saucepan. Bring to a simmer then cook for about 40 minutes or until the contents of the pot are tender.
  5. Meanwhile dry roast cassava flour until golden and sprinkle on the side when serving.

details.title: Donate Money
details.body:
Making a gift to the Comfrey Project can help in all sorts of ways and it's very easy to do. For instance:

  • £5 pays for travel and a shared lunch for one person
  • £25 pays for a person to attend one weekly garden session
  • £100 pays for an artist or cookery teacher to provide a day of workshops

You can donate money online via Local Giving, and can give a one-off donation, or a monthly commitment to our work.
